comments.commentBody: What's sad is that the only folks playing the class warfare card is the rich folks complaining about it. There are very few politicians who dare mention it. Obama alludes to it, but his appointments and policies, for whatever reason, tend to either increase income disparity, or are not effective at decreasing it.

But apparently you are okay with redistributing wealth from the middle class and poor to the rich that has been going on for 30 years?

Those billionaires have you totally bamboozled.

And right leaning pols never pander or turn Americans against each other, right?.

So tell us, what indeed was Sarah Palin really saying to an all white audience in 2008 when she called them "real Americans"?

And tell us how not rehabilitating our national infrastructure, something national governments do, would not lead to serious job creation in the private sector. Or are you counting on Wal-Mart, JP Morgan, GE and your local pizza joint to repair the bridges?

Finally, I'm curious as to how less people making more money is a solution.

The author made a small punctuation mistake. The title should have been:

The Rich Get Richer Through the "Recovery"

Because this "recovery" has been a total sham. The most laughable part is how initial estimates for GDP and non-farm payrolls are always revised lower in later releases.

But more importantly, when a "recovery" consists of spreading the wealth and taking from "the rich" to give to "the poor," what reasonable person or business would want to invest in job creation?

The focus instead should be on job creation. And to be precise: policies that lead to job creation, not bland speeches. Alas, that is probably too challenging a task for Our Dear Leader. After all, what can you expect from a President who has never worked a day in his life.

On a related note, this politics of class warfare and envy has got to stop. I, for one, am sick and tired of (left-leaning) politicians pandering to jealousy and turning Americans against each other. And I'm sick and tired of politicians using the class warfare card as a way to amass their own power.

Because--wake up!--this isn't about you, the voter! This "fairness" and "middle class" rhetoric is just a way for politicians to exploit the masses for their own power. Sad that it's so easy for them.

Here in the land of fruits and nuts (aka California), my child's preschool is required per state licensing to remove items from lunch boxes that don't meet certain nutritional guidelines. Think juice boxes that are too large or not 100% fruit juice.

Not sure which is crazier - the nanny state or that teachers have to police this.

Don't believe those ruff rumors. He was very generous and famous for picking up the tab.

I liked the northwest too.

It seems hopeless.  Unless things change, this rising inequality will lead to a bloody revolution in this country. The government should step in to prevent this inevitability. One way would be to limit total CEO income to 20 times the average blue collar worker's income.  The government already has the power to dictate salaries to private companies with the minimum wage law.  This would be setting a maximum wage.  We will always have the rich, but this country cannot afford the extremely rich aristocracy.  This way the only way the rich could increase their incomes would be by increasing our incomes. Some of the rich recognize that we need to do this, the majority don't appear to.

Mo, you're like us - old enough to know better. Old enough to know the answer to your own question, leading to the secondary question that is really paramount in our 21st century cliff-dweller existence:

" Whom do you distrust less ? "

That is the real question.

Yeah, we're also at a big, urban, low-income public school. Aside from a "no candy" rule (which is very minimally enforced), there are no rules about lunch. I always feel like mother of the year sending my children with PBJs and apple slices, because some kids just bring giant, family-sized bags of Hot Cheetos. And a soda. And the school lunch option is not much better. I do worry about these kids who eat junk food, breakfast, lunch and dinner. That's not at all your situation, KJ. Once again, the parents who are actually worrying about their parenting are not the ones to worry about.

(Your husband preventing the can of Coke for your preschooler cracked me up. I have to say he was right.)

Most people don't understand what it's like to be cripplingly needle/blood phobic, especially those in the medical profession. Take it from me: it is awful.

Needle phobia can cause extreme physical reactions. The word "phobia" is actually misleading because, for those of us with vasovagal syncope (fainting), our bodies react in the exact opposite way as they would for other phobias. Instead of hearts pounding and adrenaline racing, we start to shut down. From the time I was a toddler, I would faint if I had to go to a hospital, see medical scenes on TV, or even hear someone tell a medical story. Through a high-salt diet to raise my blood pressure, physical pressure techniques, and mental training, I have gotten a lot better. I can now excuse myself from the situation and go pass out in private, if I can make it before my vision gives out and I'm feeling around in the dark before losing consciousness.

I apologize if this sounds dramatic, but it's reality for me and millions of others with this condition. It has hindered my career choices and has made me feel like I can't be there for my family when they need me (as you pointed out above). It's also incredibly embarrassing, since many do not understand the seriousness of the situation.

So, here's my public service announcement: Needle phobia is not always something you can "get over." It's a medical condition, and I really wish people could have a little more empathy for those of us who suffer from it.
Since Kerry compared Assad to Hitler, how can President Obama now possibly do business with him like this?
What are you talking about?

Detroit and the surrounding cities are typical of most the the country, i.e., a defined-borders central city more or less surrounded by suburbs that are not part of the city. Taxes are localized because the suburbs are separate municipalities, with their own budgets and services to fund. A unified form of government -- as for example in Marion County/Indianapolis IN, in which the governments of the city of Indianapolis (but not three other cities/towns) and the county merged -- allows taxes from the suburbs to be commingled with those from the urban core. However, that is not the system in Detroit, and there is nothing inherently racist in the urban-suburban arrangement. If anything, It is classist, as middle-class blacks joined their white economic counterparts in fleeing the city.
As a current Manhattan resident and former Detroit resident I'll add my "bravo" for this cogent comment.

Detroit isn't liberal and never was. You all mistake liberalism and the Democratic party for one another. They aren't equivalent, and there is very little true liberalism anywhere in the US...and honorable conservatism has been hijacked into fascistic theocracy on one side and anarchic fantasism on another.

Detroit was a one-business town, the wealthy and professionals ran for the suburbs very early in its modern history, and the municipal government was always fairly corrupt. The thing is that after white flight, the corruption was owned - and continued - by the black urbanites, which is reasonable since they were the only ones left. Is Detroit really so badly off fiscally? Well yes, if you consider Detroit to end at the actual city limits. But Grosse Point and Birmingham, Royal Oak, Huntington Woods and all those other enormous enclaves of monied privilege inches beyond the city limits do just fine. There's a ton of money there, and they are enjoying a good life with outrageously low property prices and CoL. The residents of these suburbs made very sure that their tax dollars were profoundly localised and, unsurprisingly, Detroit itself was cut off...though they often still chose to use and abuse its remaining positive parts. If Detroit was like NYC - with boroughs tied together - it would not be in the current mess. But Detroit is a place of inherent segregationism and self-righteous "not in my backyard" selfishness. A far cry from NYC now or in the '70s.
Ed:  What about Bushie's last year, including off-budget war expenses?
Very well said, and I look forward to reading your suggested tome "No Name on the Street."  Thank you.

So many New Yorkers have been suffering through the Bloomberg years and this explains the surge for De Blasio. We understand that we live in an international city. We understand that the cost of living here is high. We understand that NYC needs tourist and corporate dollars. But what happened in the last 20 years is that the baby was thrown out with the bath water. Affordable housing evaporated, blacks were unfairly stripped of their civil rights because of white racist fear delusions (read James Baldwin's 'No Name on the Street"), and corporate interests and money took and stole and raped this city of its original storied soul. I think most New Yorkers want their city back from Bloomberg, Inc.  We want to be able to afford to live here. We also, more importantly, want to be proud to live here. And that will come from a kinder, more inclusive city. I look forward to that.

@BR: I have lived in NYC my entire life, including moving INTO Manhattan when it was at its nadir.

I don't pine for the "bad old days" when there were hookers on every block around my nabe, BUT I *do* pine for those days (which were ALSO the "good old days"!) when this city had room for "ordinary" people, when normal people who work for a living could afford an apartment, and when there was a rich diversity of mom-and-pop businesses.

I am sick of wall-to-wall banks, Duane Reades, and Starbucks, and other chain stores. I'd like the "old" NYC back in that respect, and I'd like the regular person who works for a living to have a fair chance. Under Bloomberg, NYC has gone not to the dogs, but to the oligarchs.

Sorry, BR. Violent crime has fallen dramatically since the 1990's in every major city in the US (except Detroit) regardless of whether the mayor was a Republican or Democrat. This has also occurred in Western Europe, as well. No, there will not be an increase in muggings. There are many theories for the unprecedented drop in crime; none of these theories mention Guiliani, Kelly or SQF.

NYC has radically changed for the worst in 20 years of Republican rule.  It's increasingly only a place for the affluent, who, when they "discover" a neighborhood, proceed to move there in great numbers.  As a result the affluent RUIN that neighborhood because everything that made it different and interesting is priced out of it.

Well, NYC, we had a great, 20-year run with Rudy and Bloomy. Now it's back to utter disaster. DeBlasio will be utterly unable to manage the city. Life is going to descend into the bleak, brutal old days quickly. But I can't complain. Twenty years of a livable NYC was about two decades than I ever expected. Remember this post, DeBlasio supporters, after you get mugged in a city that changes radically for the worst in very short order.
I wonder why we never say Mayor Bloomberg's family in any campaign adds during the last 12 years. Oh right, because he's single. Gee, I wonder why.

As of 11:46 pm DeBlasio has 247202 votes out of 616,965 votes or 40.006742684
percent. Multiplying the number over 40 percent by 616,965 votes he is 416 votes ahead orf a runoff. Can you say recount?
Funny how the precincts won by Quinn almost precisely overlap the zip codes of Bloombergia. Nothing more need be said.

Two good results of this election: 1) We'll soon get too see Bloomberg's deservedly smug smile as the city he ran for so well for so long collapses under DeBlasio; and 2) Quinn, my council woman lost--her office never once responded to any inquiry I made over the years. Her reputation as a simply awful person is richly earned.
Maybe Weiner will go away now?  For good?
That tiny sliver pays 50% of the city income tax. Be nice or they may move to Westchester or Nassau and then you get zero point zero.

Buh-bye, Christine Quinn!

This outcome, Ms. Quinn, is what happens when you disrespect & disregard the legally-expressed wishes of the people of NYC with your about-face on term limits.

The results of this primary election should serve as fair warning to ANY current or future candidate who is similarly inclined to shrug off referendum results they don't like.

Further, Ms. Quinn, by caving on term limits, you GAVE Bloomberg what *could* have been YOUR first term in office - you handed it to him on a silver platter.

PS: I believe you owe your spouse some time at a goat farm, which is what she said she wanted. You should have plenty of free time to do that soon.
You're voting based on the hairstyle of the candidate's son?
Why not make it official and join the Republicans?  In NYC they need all the help they can get.
The purveyor of class and race animus has been Mr. Bloomberg and the other plutocrats who have been taking from the poor to fatten themselves.

My thoughts on the national GOP could not be published here, and I have never before voted for a Republican - never even considered it. Joe Lhota will be my first. Having a son with an afro, fostering class/racial animus, and spewing hatred of the successful class doesn't govern a city. I moved to the clean, prosperous, safe New York of Messrs. Bloomberg and Giuliani; I have no intention of watching it return to the days of Abe Beame and David Dinkins.

Though, if this gay, black, and atheist Democrat is planning to vote for Mr. Lhota, I find it hard to believe Mr. de Blasio has much of a shot to begin with.

What is wrong with all these models is that they have no room for realistic financial institutions and markets, no balance sheets, and not even the possibility of a realistic financial crisis. It is a sad reflection on economics that these general equilibrium models, with 'frictions' and 'sticky wages' and all the other nonsense you use to make them fit data retrospectively, are still taken seriously. You were able to use such models for a while, until the implications of the Taylor Rule for private balance sheets and financial fragility in an economy with growing income inequality and the abandonment of serious fiscal policy made an eventual financial crisis inevitable. Time to change tack, Professor Krugman. Time to embrace the financial balances approach of Godley, the MMT of Wray, the microeconomics of Kalecki and the psychology of Kahneman - and virtually everything Minsky wrote. Then we might understand real world economies and their possibilities and constraints much better.
The Comptroller is essentially in charge of managing the City's pension funds. He is not the sheriff of Wall Street.

I think Lhota has a good chance of winning too.  For all the bluster about Bloomberg he still has high approvals and some people like me who voted for Thompson will not vote for DeBlasio as I find him way too pseudo left.  Great to get elected in a primary but in a general election who knows.  I think Thompson was a much surer thing in a general election.
I left New York because rich people were ruining my neighborhood. For the sake of those remaining, I hope your I-bankers flee to Westchester and Jersey (uh-huh) sooner rather than later.

Very silly analysis I thinks.  The rich won't flee NYC until it's underwater, this is the biggest, most cultural, most money-producing city in the country.  They can afford another grand or two in taxes, they'll just have to buy less diamond jewelry for their pomeranians.

You really think all the rich are going to leave the city? One of Bloomberg's effects was making it a status symbol to live in Manhattan (it always was, but more now than ever). These multi-millionaires/billionaires are not just going to traipse off to NJ to avoid some taxes.

I'm glad I left NYC when I did. As bad as Bloomberg was, De Blasio will be worse. After he raises taxes on "the rich," they'll all flee to NJ or Westchester. Then he'll need to raise taxes on the "not so rich" to pay for all his grand plans. Plus after he gets rid of stop-and-frisk don't be surprised when gun control stops working and the murder rate increases again. At least New Yorkers weren't dumb enough to elect Spitzer. Stringer will be a good Comptroller. At least he sees public office as public service, and not a path to more power.

Right, DRS-
Pinnacle indeed with over 30 % of the city living in poverty and so many unable to afford rent...
